questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Phospholipids

Location

Function

Synthesis

Significance

Phosphatidylserine

(Option B ruled out)

Inner leaflet of the plasma membrane

  • Involved in apoptosis.

  • It flips to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, serving as a signal for phagocytes to engulf the dying cell.

Synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

Plays a role in blood clotting by facilitating the binding of clotting factors.

Supports neuronal function.

 

Phosphatidylethanolamine

(Option C ruled out)

 

All cellular membranes

  • Important for membrane fusion and the structural integrity of cellular membranes.

  • Serves as a precursor for the synthesis of phosphatidylserine.

Synthesized in the ER via the cytidine diphosphate-ethanolamine (CDP-ethanolamine) pathway or by decarboxylation of phosphatidylserine in the mitochondria.
  • Plays a role in lipid metabolism and membrane dynamics.
  • Deficiencies can impact cellular functions and are associated with various neurological disorders.

Phosphatidylinositol

(Option D ruled out)

 

plasma membrane and intracellular membranes

  • Involved in cell signaling pathways, particularly through the production of secondary messengers

  • Plays a role in membrane trafficking and cytoskeletal organization.

Produced in the ER and Golgi apparatus from CDP-DAG and inositol.
  • Crucial for the function of insulin signaling and other receptor-mediated signal transduction pathways.
  • Defects in phosphatidylinositol metabolism are linked to various diseases, including diabetes and cancer.

questions.text: Hypoxic Hypoxia is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Type of Hypoxia

Etiology

Examples

PaCO2

PaO2

Cyanosis

Hypoxic Hypoxia

Inadequate oxygen supply or impaired utilization

High altitude, CO poisoning, HCN poisoning, respiratory diseases

Normal

Low

Present

Anemic Hypoxia

Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood

Anemia, blood loss, hemoglobinopathies, carbon monoxide poisoning

Normal

Low

Present

Stagnant Hypoxia

Impaired blood flow or reduced circulation

Heart failure, shock, circulatory disorders, vasoconstriction

Normal

Low

Present

Histotoxic Hypoxia

Inability of cells to utilize oxygen effectively due to toxic substances or metabolic disorders

Cyanide poisoning, certain metabolic disorders

Variable

Variable

May be absent or mild

1.

Hypoxic hypoxia

Low SaO2 and low SvO2

Cyanosis ++

2.

Anemic hypoxia

1. Anaemia (Low Hb)

2. CO- poisoning

3. Meth- Hb (brown colour)

1. Cyanosis is rare

2. No cyanosis

3. cyanosis like appearance can be seen as not true cyanosis.

3.

Stagnant hypoxia

Very low SvO2

Cyanosis ++

4.

Histotoxic hypoxia

SaO2 is Normal and high SvO2

Cyanosis never seen

questions.text: What would be the resulting lung volume if the chest wall is excluded and the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil?
questions.explanation:
Lung Volumes

Definition

Tidal Volume

Volume of air inspired or expired during normal breathing

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)

Maximum volume of air that can be inspired above tidal volume

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)

Maximum volume of air that can be expired below tidal volume

Residual Volume (RV)

Volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximal expiration

Inspiratory Capacity

Total volume of air that can be inspired after tidal expiration (TV + IRV)

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

Volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration (ERV + RV)

Vital Capacity

Maximum volume of air that can be forcefully exhaled after maximal inspiration (TV + IRV + ERV)

Total Lung Capacity

Maximum volume of air the lungs can hold (TV + IRV + ERV + RV)

questions.text: Surfactant is secreted by which of the following?
The O 2 saturation with respect to PO₂ is marked as A. What happens to the Oxygen Hb dissociation curve upon transfusion of stored RBC?
questions.explanation:
Factor

Effect on O₂ Dissociation Curve

Impact

Low 2,3-BPG

Leftward shift (B)

Increased O₂ affinity, reduced unloading

Acidosis

Rightward shift

Enhances oxygen unloading

Alkalosis

Leftward shift

Increases oxygen binding

Hypercapnia (↑ CO₂)

Rightward shift

Enhances oxygen release

Hypothermia

Leftward shift

Decreases oxygen unloading

questions.text: Determine the respiratory quotient (RQ) of a patient weighing 50 kg who exhales 200 ml/min of CO 2 and consumed 250 ml/min 02 .

During exercise, once a state of balance is achieved, it was observed that the body's oxygen consumption rate was 1500 ml/min. To determine the MET score, consider a baseline oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min.
Which ion is primarily involved in the function of O2-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors?
Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to?
questions.explanation:
Stimulus

Effect on Peripheral Chemoreceptors

Hypoxia (↓ PaO₂)

Strongest stimulus, leading to increased ventilation.

Hypercapnia (↑ PaCO₂)

Weak response; central chemoreceptors dominate.

Acidosis (↓ pH)

Peripheral response occurs, but central chemoreceptors are more significant.

Alkalosis (↑ pH)

Minimal effect; detected mainly by central chemoreceptors.

questions.text: Physiological dead space?

options.label: B
options.text: Is lesser than anatomical dead space

questions.explanation:
Concept

Description

Anatomical Dead Space

Conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs (e.g., trachea, bronchi).

Alveolar Dead Space

Alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused, contributing to wasted ventilation.

Physiological Dead Space

Sum of anatomical and alveolar dead space; reflects ineffective ventilation.

questions.text: A patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1%. What is the most probable diagnosis?

questions.explanation:
Lung Volume/Capacity

Description

Typical Volume (mL)

Formula

Tidal Volume (TV) (Option B ruled out)

Amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breath

500

-

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) (Option D ruled out)

Additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation

3000

-

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) (Option C ruled out)

Additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation

1200

-

Residual Volume (RV)

Air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation

1200

-

Anatomical Dead Space

Volume of air in conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs

150

-

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Maximum amount of air the lungs can hold

6000

TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV

Vital Capacity (VC)

Maximum air exhaled after a maximal inhalation

4800

VC = TV + IRV + ERV

Inspiratory Capacity (IC)

Maximum air inhaled after a normal exhalation

3500

IC = TV + IRV

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) (Option A)

Air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation

2400

FRC = ERV + RV

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?

options.label: C
options.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased

options.label: D
options.text: Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.correct_answer: B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance decreased

questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Single breath nitrogen test:

questions.text: Adequate oxygen delivery at cellular level is present in which type of hypoxia ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - H

questions.text: Adequate O 2 oxygen delivery at cellular level occurs in which type of hypoxia?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - H

Type of Hypoxia

Cause

Description

Hypoxic Hypoxia

Decreased inspired oxygen or impaired gas exchange in lungs

Insufficient oxygen tension in arterial blood

Anaemic Hypoxia

Decreased oxygen-carrying capacity of blood

Reduced hemoglobin levels or abnormal hemoglobin function

Stagnant Hypoxia

Impaired blood circulation

Reduced blood flow to tissues

Histotoxic Hypoxia

Cellular inability to utilize oxygen

Disruption in the cellular metabolic process

questions.text: Which of the following breathing patterns have prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Apneustic breathing:

questions.text: Functional residua l capacity is:

options.label: B
options.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.correct_answer: C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume: 

Lung Volume/Capacity

Description

Typical Value (in adults)

Tidal Volume (TV)

Volume of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing

500 mL

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)

Additional volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal inspiration

2,500-3,000 mL

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)

Additional volume of air that can be exhaled after a normal tidal expiration

1,000-1,200 mL

Residual Volume (RV)

Volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximal expiration

1,200-1,300 mL

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Maximum volume of air the lungs can hold, including inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume

5,000-6,000 mL

Vital Capacity (VC)

Maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inspiration, including inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume

4,500-5,000 mL

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

Volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal tidal expiration, including expiratory reserve volume and residual volume

2,400-2,800 mL

Inspiratory Capacity (IC)

Maximum volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal expiration, including tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume

3,500-3,800 mL
